perturbation.original_text: Either Party may terminate this Agreement by giving the other Party thirty (30) days' prior written notice.
perturbation.changed_text: Either Party may terminate this Agreement by giving the other Party five (5) days' prior written notice.
perturbation.explanation: California law, which governs this agreement according to section 4.10, often requires longer notice periods for contract termination to ensure sufficient time for parties to wind down affairs or find alternative arrangements. A five-day notice period may be deemed unreasonably short and thus conflict with the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under California contract law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California law regarding reasonable notice periods for contract termination and the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.

perturbation.original_text:
This Agreement and all rights and licenses granted under this Agreement shall terminate as soon as practicable, but no longer than
thirty (30) days, after:
3.2.1 Licensee is acquired by a third party; or
3.2.2 Licensor or any affiliate of Licensor ceases to manage Licensee.
perturbation.changed_text:
This Agreement and all rights and licenses granted under this Agreement shall terminate as soon as practicable, but no longer than
ten (10) days, after:
3.2.1 Licensee is acquired by a third party; or
3.2.2 Licensor or any affiliate of Licensor ceases to manage Licensee.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the termination timeframe to ten days after an acquisition of the Licensee or cessation of management by the Licensor's affiliate may be considered an unreasonably short period under California law, potentially conflicting with the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. A shorter period can severely impair the Licensee's ability to transition its business operations or secure alternative licensing arrangements, especially given the complexities often involved in corporate acquisitions or management changes. This change introduces a potential breach of fiduciary duty depending on the relationship between Licensor and Licensee.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California law regarding reasonable timeframes in contract termination, the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, and fiduciary duties.

perturbation.original_text:
Upon termination of this Agreement, Licensed Users shall immediately cease use of the Licensed Trade Name and Licensed Mark as
soon as practicable, but no longer than thirty (30) days, after termination.
perturbation.changed_text: Upon termination of this Agreement, Licensed Users shall immediately cease use of the Licensed Trade Name and Licensed Mark within five (5) days after termination.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the period to cease using the Licensed Trade Name and Licensed Mark to 5 days might not allow a reasonable transition period, particularly considering California's laws protecting businesses from undue hardship. This could contradict the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, especially if the Licensee requires more time to rebrand or adjust marketing materials. The California Consumer Legal Remedies Act also addresses unfair practices, and such a short timeframe might be argued as imposing unfair or oppressive terms.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California's implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, California Consumer Legal Remedies Act, and general principles of contract law regarding reasonable timeframes.
